data.title: Preserve specificity when transforming atom-text-editor::shadow
data.body:
Simply replace ::shadow with .editor to preserve the specificity of the transformed rule. This isn't beautiful, but it's the only way to guarantee that the styling transition is smooth enough to justify not bumping the major.

It would be great if some people that had styling regressions due to specificity could give this build a spin and see if things would have been okay if we transformed this way.

Closes #13019

/cc @as-cii @atom/maintainers @abe33

data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

* [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

Applications are launched from randomised paths in macOS Sierra

See also [Sierra and Gatekeeper Path Randomization](https://weblog.rogueamoeba.com/2016/06/29/sierra-and-gatekeeper-path-randomization/)

Unfortunately, this means that the `/usr/local/bin/{atom,apm}` symbolic links that Atom installs are only valid until the next time macOS randomises the application path.

`ls -la /usr/local/bin/atom`

> lrwxr-xr-x  1 ron  admin  152  1 Nov 09:51 /usr/local/bin/atom -> /private/var/folders/mx/_pq4c8yx2nl1h05ht_w2m1y40000gn/T/AppTranslocation/C40BC339-2DD1-4FDF-8516-E966D4B4D45D/d/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/atom.sh

Possibly related to #12126

### Steps to Reproduce

1. install Atom
2. launch Atom from Finder / Dock / Spotlight
3. Atom (menu) -> Install Shell Commands
4. launch Terminal
5. `atom --help` and observe that it works
6. completely exit Atom and with a few minutes, or reboot macOS
7. launch Terminal
8. `atom --help` and observe the "command not found: atom" error message

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

`atom` and `apm` shell commands should continue to work correctly once installed

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

`atom` and `apm` shell commands only work reliably while Atom is open, and only after being reinstalled at least once

### Versions

data.title: Raising exceptions in test mode (Issue: #10079)
Feature request: Provide an AppImage for Atom Stable and Atom Beta releases
data.body:
Hi,

As @probonopd, the developer of the AppImage format, has requested I do this in [probonopd/AppImages#118](https://github.com/probonopd/AppImages/issues/118#issuecomment-257396828), I have decided to request that this provide provides official AppImage builds for Atom Stable and Atom Beta releases. AppImages are a cross-distribution (but very much Linux-specific, in case you're wondering whether they'd run on FreeBSD) package format that are essentially self-mounting disk images with all the required libraries and executables inside to run the app they provide (in the case of an Atom AppImage this would be Atom, of course). They are similar, in this regard, to `.dmg` (or disk image) files for macOS. I realize this project already provides tarball builds for Atom, but AppImages do not need to be extracted in order to be run, unlike tarball builds. AppImages are extremely easy to build, including from your Travis CI artefacts. 

And yes, I know that AppImages have been previously discussed in this bugtracker, see for example atom/atom#4980. But I would like to make a formal and specific request (as opposed to issue 4980, which merely requested a portable package format for Linux and did not specifically request an AppImage) for them to be provided. 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton

data.title: Can't tell if a marker has been decorated synchronously
data.body:
There's currently no API that can be used to detect whether a marker has actually been decorated or not (if the class has been added)

This creates race conditions for me if I wanted to do something with the class on its creation. For example currently  doing something like this doesn't work:

```
decoration = editor.decorateMarker(marker, type: type, class: "my-special-class")
edview = atom.views.getView(atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()
match = edview.shadowRoot.querySelector(".my-special-class")
```

match would return null, However if we put the querySelector call in a setTimeout's callback set to something like ~100 ms it would then work.

I tried using a MutationObserver but that didn't make a difference, it too required a setTimeout's callback to work 

```
observer = new MutationObserver (mutations) ->
  for mutation in mutations
    stocb = ->
      match = edview.shadowRoot.querySelector("my-special-class")
      if (match != null)
        #Our decoration has finally been added
        #We don't need to observe the tree for it anymore
        observer.disconnect();
        #Get our jQueryObject and play around with it
        jQueryObject = View.$(match)
        jQueryObject.mouseover (ev) =>
          console.log("moused over!")
        decoration.onDidDestroy () =>
          #once the decoration is gone
          #we have to stop tracking the line-number div
          jQueryObject.off()
    #
    setTimeout stocb, 10


#configuration of the observer:
config = { attributes: true, subtree: true };

# pass in the target node, as well as the observer options
observer.observe(edview, config);
```

Hopefully we can get something a callback parameter (which takes a cb and calls it once the decoration's been added...)

I see something like 
 ```
setUpdatedSynchronously: (@updatedSynchronously) ->
```
In https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/decoration-manager.coffee
but this class doesn't seem to be documented

data.title: Multi-cursor movement shouldn't jump to the last cursor
data.body:
Repro steps:
- Open a file with a few hundred lines
- Find a word that's used in many parts of the file
- cmd-ctrl-g on this word to create a cursor on all the occurrences
- see that it moves to the last occurrence. **Intended behavior:** shouldn't move
- scroll all the way up to the first occurrence
- hit the right arrow
- see that it moves to the last occurrence. **Intended behavior:** shouldn't move

Why does it happen?

The screen movement logic is encoded in the single cursor implementation:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/0e992326154d387611543f618ad5872dc4665586/src/cursor.coffee#L255-L268

And the cursor movement action just delegates to all the cursors:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f726dcc81bcd88eb7aff1e61bd77484b875f0854/src/text-editor.coffee#L2153-L2154

So, what happens is that we're going to iterate over all the cursors, and set the screen position on all of them and the last one is going to win.

Instead, **what should happen** is that if the screen is currently under any of the cursors, don't move. If not, then find the nearest cursor and move to that one, instead of the last one.

cc @nathansobo do you have advice on how I can refactor this piece of code to solve the issue?

### Description

Since Atom 1.12 beta the paths of files on network mapped drives are resolved with the full server name instead of the path of the network mapped drive. This caused problems with restoring the session of projects on network mapped drives when upgrading to Atom 1.12.

Example: `\\server\path\to\folder` is mapped to `Y:\`. Atom restores the session with the `Y:\` path but all new files open with the `\\server\path\to\folder` path. So you have to close and reopen all files you previously had opened to not have duplicate files open. This also can cause the UNC path error when running the linter on beta.

I did discover that the `tree-view` still has the old path if you copy the full path of some file and the title bar of Atom also displays the network mapped drive label. So currently we display both of the paths in different parts of Atom.
##### Atom 1.12.0-beta5 paths

![path stuff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/19836364/6d5ec3dc-9e9e-11e6-955e-bc29966a3d65.gif)
##### Atom 1.11.2 paths

![path stuff 1 11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/19836376/21a003a6-9e9f-11e6-8e65-6519716dfa3c.gif)
##### Upgrading from 1.11 to 1.12

![path stuff upgrade](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/19836383/6b5bae64-9e9f-11e6-952b-079c82ef0cc0.gif)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install Atom 1.11.2
2. Map a network drive on Windows
3. Open a folder on the network mapped drive
4. Open some files for example: `Y:\file.txt`
5. Install Atom 1.12-beta5
6. Paths from previous session restore as `Y:\file.txt`
7. Open `Y:\file.txt` from the `tree-view` a duplicate tab opens as `\\server\path\to\folder\file.txt`

**Expected behavior:** Paths to be consistent across Atom. Upgrade to be smooth so users don't have to close every file after upgrading to avoid opening duplicate files.

**Actual behavior:** Paths are inconsistent. Upgrade from 1.11 to 1.12 not smooth.

data.title: Per-package transpilation
data.body:
This is a ~~WIP and (thus far) rough~~ implementation of per-package transpilation pipelines mentioned in #13087. It allows packages to opt in to fully managing their own transpilation steps, bypassing the built-in Atom transpilation entirely. Here's roughly how it works:
1. A package declares a property in its `package.json` called `atomTranspilers`. This is an array of objects, with each object specifying `glob`, `transpiler`, and optionally `options`.
2. When a package is loaded, if `atomTranspilers` exists in its metadata, we notify the `CompileCache` that it wants to do its own compilation.
3. A new class called `PackageTranspilationRegistry` wraps all the `CompileCache` compilers with a new object of the same interface that falls back to the original compiler if a package hasn't opted in to its own transpilation, but bypasses it completely otherwise.
4. If a package is doing it's own compilation, then for each file that matches the `glob` specified, the associated `transpiler` is required, and the exported value should be an object with a function called `compile` that takes three arguments: `sourceCode`, `filePath`, and `options` (where `options` comes from the package's `package.json`). It should return a string or Buffer with the transpiled source, or `undefined` to indicate that it doesn't want to transpile that file. Note that returning `undefined` doesn't fall back to the legacy, core behavior — packages which opt in to this mechanism are _fully_ responsible for _all_ their transpilation.

Also worth noting is that the transpiler file cannot be transpiled itself; its source must run in a vanilla Atom environment (which is admittedly pretty capable these days :).

One question I have is how to handle the caching. For example, I currently have `getCachePath` set to

``` javascript
return path.join(
  "package-transpile",
  crypto
    .createHash('sha1')
    .update(transpilerSource, 'utf8')
    .update(sourceCode, 'utf8')
    .digest('hex')
  )
```

but in many cases it's possible that neither the file's source nor the transpiler's source has changed, but the output of transpilation would be different (e.g. when editing a `.babelrc` file). Perhaps we should allow the package author to also specify a cache key for the file?

/cc @nathansobo @atom/core for early 💭

data.title: Fix toggleLineCommentsInSelection for empty lines
data.body:
### Description of the Change

This code:

``` coffee
scope = @editor.scopeDescriptorForBufferPosition([start, 0])
commentStrings = @editor.getCommentStrings(scope)
```

Returns `Object {commentStartString: undefined, commentEndString: undefined}` if the language doesn't have comments. For example with `text.plain.null-grammar`.

Which causes this check in `LanguageMode.toggleLineCommentsForBufferRows`

``` coffee
return unless commentStrings?
```

To not return. Meaning `LanguageMode.toggleLineCommentsForBufferRows` will run even when there is no comment defined for the current language.
Which means that if the line is empty and the language doesn't have a defined comment we print `undefined` in the `TextEditor`.

This PR adds a check to return early if there is no `commentStartString`.
### Alternate Designs

Change the return value to `null` instead of returning an object with `undefined` properties for languages with no defined comments.
### Benefits
1. Fixes bug!
2. Doesn't write `undefined` in the `TextEditor` when trying comment an empty line when the comment is `undefined`!
3. Adds a test to not regress!

### Possible Drawbacks
- We can't add a language that only has a `commentEndString`?

### Applicable Issues

None

/cc: @nathansobo

data.title: Introduce follow through behavior for tooltips
data.body:
Inside of Nuclide, we have multiple places where we have multiple icons close together that have a tooltip: the left toolbar, the bottom status bar, the debugger icons...

The current behavior is very frustrating as you've got to wait for the delay on every single one of them. But, we have a clear signal that the user wants a tooltip when s/he waits the time to see it and it's likely that moving the mouse over the next item quickly means that s/he wants to see it as well.

This pull request introduces the concept of follow through: if you have seen a tooltip, you're going to instantly see tooltip on the next element you mouse over within a short timer (300ms right now).
